content: The "Business Improvement Act of 1993" allows contracts awarded to program participants before the enactment of the Act to be considered for business activity targets under the Small Business Act. SEC. 3. PROCUREMENT PROCEDURES. Section 8 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow participating agencies to enter into contracts with small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals through restricted competition or a price evaluation preference of up to 10 percent. Section 8 of the Small Business Act allows participating agencies to contract with small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals through restricted competition or a price evaluation preference of up to 10 percent. The authority provided in this subsection remains effective until September 30, 2000. ELIGIBILITY OF PAST DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS FOR SECTION 8(a) CONTRACT AWARDS. Section (8)(a)(1)(C) of the Small Business Act is amended to allow awarding contracts to small businesses owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals who have completed their Program Participation period as prescribed by section 7(j)(15). This applies to both competitive and sole source awards. The Small Business Act allows contracts to be awarded to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals who have completed their Program Participation period. Sole source awards can be given if the prospective awardee was eligible on the date of submitting certifications to the agency. SEC. 5 amends Section 8(a)(1) of the Small Business Act by removing competitive contracts and SEC. 6 ensures continued access to business opportunities. Section 8(a)(3) of the Small Business Act is amended to require competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency if there is a reasonable expectation of offers from 2 or more eligible small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals capable of performing the contract. The Small Business Act requires competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency if there are offers from 2 or more eligible small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals capable of performing the contract. The head of a participating agency must restrict competition for the award of a contract to ensure that the contractor currently performing a similar contract has graduated from the small business development program prior to the solicitation issuance. The Small Business Act requires competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency. The competition for the award of a contract is described in clause (i) to small business concerns owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. A small business concern described in clause (i)(III) shall be eligible for award of a contract resulting from a restricted competition if they agree to subcontract 20-50% of the award value. The Small Business Act requires competition for contracts to furnish products or services to a participating agency, with a focus on small business concerns owned by disadvantaged individuals. Contracts may require subcontracting a percentage of the award value to small businesses in the developmental stage of the minority small business program. Additionally, follow-on contracts for similar products or services should also be awarded under the same authority. The Small Business Act requires contracts to be awarded to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals, with a focus on subcontracting to minority small businesses. A participating agency is defined as any Federal agency, and a small business is defined as having no more than 1500 employees. SEC. 7. STUDY OF DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM PARTICIPATION TERMS BY INDUSTRY SECTOR; SUSPENSION OF DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GRADUATIONS. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize a short-term study to determine program participation terms by industry sector for small businesses. Results of the study must be transmitted to key government bodies within 1 year. The Small Business Act is amended to allow small businesses participating in programs or activities under certain clauses to continue their eligibility until 365 days after October 1, 1992. Small businesses participating in programs can maintain eligibility until 365 days after final regulations are issued or the expiration date based on program requirements. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE WITH BUY INDIAN ACT. Federal agencies contracting with the Small Business Administration under section 8(a) of the Small Business Act for goods or services from economically disadvantaged Indian tribes are considered compliant with the Buy Indian Act. SEC. 9. UNIFORM PROCEDURES FOR CONTESTING STATUS OF CONCERNS. SEC. 9. UNIFORM PROCEDURES FOR CONTESTING STATUS OF CONCERNS. An amendment to the Small Business Act requires the Administrator to establish uniform procedures for contesting the status of a concern as a 'small business concern owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals' within 120 days.
